text: Hey Juan - I believe you can only add classes to the dnd_area. The alternative is just to add a wrapping class at the root of your module.html and use that. (works when you’re using custom modules only obviously)
right, but sometimes we need to add a class to the section containing the modules
and the class for the specific section or row changes when the user reorder the section
i assum i could create a module that wraps content inside a section that can host other modules
I’d say it makes sense - things would get pretty unwieldy otherwise.
I personally think the key to a good development experience on HS is making sure you treat each module as an isolated component.

right, but it still make sense for sections to have their own identifiers like everything else, that way you could treat modules as single units and use the section to apply grid without having to add more HTML
with the unique id you can move around the entire section if needed without breaking styles
modules can be single units, but they are not the only units, sections are units as well
it could help to modularize CSS as well, like creating skins for sections using a class `section-with-grid` , `section-with-dark-bg` , etc
Yeah, but I guess it’s also important to look at it from a content editor point of view - and how you’d present that.

I do think sections need looking at from a content editing experience - at the moment there is limited options and it really doesn’t tie into the overall module editing experience very cleaning - especially if you have just 1 module in a section.
correct, okay yeah from that perspective it makes sense
